title: M7: Two-dimensional embeddings and encoder attention
authorComments: * DIFFICULTY: advanced. * SUPERVISION: teacher-guided. * ESTIMATED ANSWERING TIME: 30 minutes. * LANGUAGE-SPECIFIC CONTENT: English. * ADAPTATION TO OTHER LANGUAGES: the sentence used in the activity must be replaced with one containing related words that allow the student to infer a similar answer; a translation of the sentence may be valid. * COMMENTS FOR INSTRUCTORS: this question focuses on both the non-contextual and contextual embeddings discussed in chapter 7 of the book. The student will draw a square and put related words such as "waking" and "blanket" (or prepositions such as "inside" or "without") close to each other. There are infinite attention vectors that can be used to produce a contextual embedding for "waking" but the idea is that students justify their decision; a linguistically motivated answer could consider attending "Harry Potter" (subject of the verb), "blankets" (semantically related), "without" (preceding preposition), "up" (the other element in the phrasal verb) and, obviously, "waking", therefore making up a vector [5%, 10%, 0%, 0%, 0%, 0%, 20%, 10%, 30%, 25%].
